awd_titl_txt: Searches for New Phenomena at the Energy Frontier
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will provide support to a Northern Illinois University group working on the ATLAS experiment at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) at CERN, a particle physics laboratory in Geneva, Switzerland. The LHC machine and ATLAS, a large particle detector facility, were built as basic science tools using funds from NSF and other agencies around the world. One of their primary objectives was to find the Higgs Boson, the last particle in the historically successful "Standard Model" (SM) that accounts for so much of the existence of, and forces between, known particles forming the matter in the universe. This effort has been successful. The next step in the experiments is to study the properties and characteristics of this newly discovered particle as a laboratory to see if it behaves as the SM predicts or if there are deviations suggesting evidence for new physics Beyond the Standard Model (BSM) that might, for instance, account for the presence of the mysterious "Dark Matter" that makes up so much of the mass of the universe. This group will participate in these studies.  The LHC is currently in the midst of Run 2, at almost twice the energy explored earlier and with significantly increased event samples. It is possible that evidence for BSM physics could emerge at this higher energy and with the higher event statistics from the current run and by means of further upgrades of the LHC and ATLAS to follow.

To facilitate a detailed study of the Higgs Boson and search for other new states of matter, the NIU group will be focusing their studies on Higgs couplings, including self-coupling, in order to determine whether this particle is the sole Higgs boson postulated in the Standard Model, or one of multiple neutral scalar bosons postulated in various BSM scenarios. Much of the analytical effort is focused on searches for pair production of the only Higgs particle discovered so far.   Additionally the group has had a long-standing interest in the ATLAS searches for charged Higgs bosons featured in certain extended Higgs models, and in differential cross section measurements of Higgs boson decays into two gamma rays.  

The NIU group is also engaged in the Phase 2 Upgrade of the TileCAL, hadronic calorimeter, and experimental subsystem essential for energy and missing energy measurements, and in advanced Fast Track Triggering for the experiment called the FTK, which is central to being able to trigger on important physics objectives as the LHC luminosity increases.

An integral part of the NIU group activity is outreach to K-12 students, teachers, and the general public.  Their program includes an active QuarkNet center at NIU that hosts annual one-day masterclasses, week-long workshops, and 6-8-week summer internships.  The group is also active in a variety of programs to engage the public, some hosted at NIU and others at nearby Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
One of the major goals of the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) is using the Higgs boson as a tool to explore the Standard Model (SM) of particle physics and to look for physics beyond the SM (BSM). Using proton-proton collision data from the ATLAS experiment, located at the LHC, this grant made precision tests of the SM and searched for BSM physics in the Higgs sector. The PI and his student led publication of precision, differential cross section measurements of Higgs boson production in channels where the Higgs boson decays to a pair of photons. The measurements probed things like Higgs boson momentum, specific Higgs boson production modes, angles and distances between objects and things like numbers of jets. Each of these measurements is sensitive to different effects, including indirect influence of BSM physics, modeling of Higgs boson production and knowledge of the distribution of quarks and gluons inside of the protons. No significant discrepancies were observed. The expertise developed in this analysis was then used to kick-start a new analysis aiming to measure the production of pairs of photons with associated heavy flavor (b,c) jets (yyHF). This final state has never been measured before at the LHC, and no explicit predictions for it exist in the literature. It is an important background for several important analyses in the diphoton final state, including hh and tth measurements, and as such, this novel work is an important piece of future LHC studies. The yyHF analysis has advanced significantly over the timeline of this grant, and is moving soon towards internal ATLAS review.


The NIU team has also searched for pair production of Higgs bosons, one of the key long-term goals of the LHC. The group made contributions in the multi-lepton and ditau+bb final states, and helped to lead ATLAS efforts in publication of the diphoton+bb final state search. Studying pair production of the Higgs boson is critical, as it tells physicists about how Higgs bosons self-interact, and provides stringent tests of electroweak symmetry breaking (which is why electricity and magnetism are long-range forces but the weak force, responsible for radioactive decays, is not). Though hh production has not yet been observed, limits on Higgs boson self interactions are already starting to probe interesting regions of phase space.

In addition, the NIU team more directly probed BSM physics by searching for production of a new, electrically charged Higgs boson (H+) decaying to a tau. Such new particles are predicted in many extensions of the SM. The NIU team made critical contributions to an earlier publication of this search (which did not find any evidence of H+), and developed a novel parameterized neural network to search for H+ in the full Run 2 data set. The NIU group also helped to push forward searches for lepton-flavor-violating (LFV) decays of the SM-like Higgs boson in e+tau and mu+tau final states, analyses that are now far advanced, and has just begun searches for vector-like B quarks in the diphoton final state.

Outside of direct physics searches, the NIU group has made important contributions to the objects used in these searches, including tau identification performance studies and first efforts at learning how to calibrate multivariate-based photon ID. The group has also aided ATLAS by ensuring that the quality of data from the tile calorimeter is well calibrated and well understood such that it can be used by all experimental collaborators. Finally, the team has focused on the future of ATLAS by working on both tile upgrade and track trigger upgrades for the High Luminosity LHC (HL-LHC). The track trigger upgrade was formerly the HTT project, but the NIU team helped to lead efforts to change this project from a purely hardware-based solution to a more modern commodity architecture solution (EF Tracking). Group members play important leadership roles on EF Tracking and also make critical contributions to performance, algorithm and simulation studies. They also have helped to lead coordination of simulated sample production for the HL-LHC.
